none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, February 26, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, February 26, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 11 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Letter from J. T. Hand in Brenham to Louis L. McInnis discussing academic career advancement and university appointments in Texas, including competition for professorial chairs at a newly organizing university. Hand offers strategic advice on securing academic positions, mentions the importance of faculty endorsements and active self-promotion, and comments on the politics of higher education administration and the university's organization plans.

body.value:
Brenham Feb. 26th 188[?]

My dear Professor:

Your welcome letter
was received last Thursday.
Thursday & Friday were occupied with
our Monthly Written Examinations -
Papers - papers & reports - ad nauseam -
until 12 o'clock Saturday night.
I embrace the first leisure to reply.
If Prof. R. were not a member of
the Board of Regents he would
present but a small obstacle in
the way of your elevating to the
position you desire. Since he is
a member of the Board he has,
in my judgment the "inside track"
for the Chair to which he aspires.
You know the influence of organized
association. If Austin Chair
suits your taste as well or better,
I think fewer obstacles to its attainment
would be presented. I should
rejoice at your success & would
regret your defeat.

**Here's the Transcription and Interpretation**

Okay, so I'm presented with a handwritten letter and the task of producing a high-accuracy digital transcription, preserving the intent and structure of the original document as best as possible. The primary goal is to produce a transcription that can be easily parsed and used in some academic context or historical research. I begin by scanning the letter and breaking it down into component parts:

*   **Header and Date:** I first note the apparent date and location at the top. The date, "Brenham Feb. 26th 188[?]", is slightly obscured, and I'll need to double-check that last digit, though it looks most like a '2' or '5', and I will add a `[?]` to mark my uncertainty.
*   **Salutation:** Next comes the salutation, "My dear Professor:".
*   **Content:** Then I move on to the body. This requires careful reading and character-by-character analysis. I'll need to identify any abbreviations or specialized terms.
*   **Paragraph Structure:** The layout looks a bit irregular. But by examining the indentation, I'll attempt to understand how the writer intended the flow of thought to be. I see some indentation which seems to mark clear paragraph breaks, though the letter is continuous and would read better as a single block in prose.

I will construct the text in paragraph format, as that's the clearest. There are four obvious paragraph breaks, as determined by visual indentation and logical breaks in the text. I'll write the transcription in that order.

Now, I'll provide the transcription line by line:

Brenham Feb. 26th 188[?]

My dear Professor:

Your welcome letter was received last Thursday.

Thursday & Friday were occupied with our Monthly Written Examinations - Papers - papers & reports - ad nauseam - until 12 o'clock Saturday night.

I embrace the first leisure to reply.

If Prof. R. were not a member of the Board of Regents he would present but a small obstacle in the way of your elevating to the position you desire. Since he is a member of the Board he has, in my judgment the "inside track" for the Chair to which he aspires. You know the influence of organized association. If Austin Chair suits your taste as well or better, I think fewer obstacles to its attainment would be presented. I should rejoice at your success & would regret your defeat.

After transcribing, I will do a final proofread to verify spelling, capitalization, and punctuation. Then, I will confirm my work is accurate and complete, ready for use!

[Header]
[1882. Feb 26]

These are my candid convictions.
I wish you had not only "a half
mind to run down to Benham" - but a
whole one. Can't you? We can
talk many things that we can't write.
Allow me to suggest that the times
of the Success of Modest Merit have
passed. In these latter days,
if a man wants a thing he
is expected to ask for it & back
himself up with all supports.
In our "trade", fitness alone should
determine the question of preferment,
but alas! it is not so. In a late
conversation with Major Baker
he stated that his mind turned to
me when a late vacancy occurred
in Horsley, but in the absence of
any application from me he supposed
I was well cared for in Benham &
intimated that I had slept over
my privilege. I bowed & retired.
I give this as an instance simply
of the customs of our times.

**Here's the Transcription of the Letter**

Okay, so I've got this handwritten letter in front of me, and my task is to get a really accurate transcription. Let's break this down. First, I'm noting the date in the top right, written in pencil, which looks like *[1882. Feb 26]*.  It's late 19th-century cursive, so some words need careful examination.  The writer seems to be sharing some personal thoughts ("candid convictions") with someone, and they really want this person to visit them in Benham. They're also talking about success, modesty ("Modest Merit"), and it seems like there's a reference to a "Major Baker" and a recent job vacancy in either Horsley or Hoseley. I'm going to carefully transcribe it, line by line.

So, here's what I'm transcribing:

[1882. Feb 26]

These are my candid convictions.
I wish you had not only "a half
mind to run down to Benham" - but a
whole one. Can't you? We can
talk many things that we can't write.
Allow me to suggest that the times
of the success of Modest Merit have
passed. In these latter days,
if a man wants a thing he
is expected to *ask* for it & back
himself up with all supports.
In our "trade", *fitness* alone should
determine the question of preferment,
but alas! it is not so. In a late
conversation with Major Baker
he stated that his mind turned to
me when a late vacancy occurred
in Horsley, but in the absence of
any application from me he supposed
I was well cared for in Benham &
intimated that I had slept over
my privilege. I bowed & retired.
I give this as an instance simply
of the customs of our times.

I'm using *i* for emphasis because that's the only way to indicate an underlined word in the output format.
Double-checking my work for the formatting, I am keeping that format and using HTML tags like `p`, `b`, and `i` to represent emphasis, and using brackets for the date. It is a single paragraph. "Benham", "Horsley", and "Modest Merit" look clear. I've double-checked the quotes on "trade" and "a half". I'm pretty confident in the transcription, now.  "Horsley" seems right.

[Header]
[1883, Feb. 26]

There will be little less than 100
applicants for the different Chairs
in the Uni- when organized.
I think a strong "endorsation" of
of the faculty of the Univ of Miss.
would be of great value to you.
If I can serve you command me.

I think now that I shall apply
for the Chair of Latin or Greek or both
should they be combined. I am
aware that O. H. C..... is being
"coached" for that Chair - with
chances of success in his favor.
He will return to Texas backed by
the faculty of Yale & you know
"Distance lends enchantment to the view"

My information in regard to the organi-
zation of the Univ is meager indeed -
I am not apprised even of the
action of the Regents at their late
meeting in Austin. When do you
think the Univ will be organized?

Suppose there will be a doz or 15
Chairs provided with Tutorships in
some of them at least.

`. Final transcription should look like this. I will carefully render the text. The double "of" will be typed exactly as it looks. The date in brackets will be typed, line by line. I am now ready to begin the final transcription. ```html

applicants for the different Chairs
in the Uni- when organized.

of the faculty of the Univ of Miss.
would be of great value to you.
If I can serve you command me.

I think now that I shall apply
for the Chair of Latin or Greek or both
should they be combined. I am
aware that O. H. C..... is being
"coached" for that Chair - with
chances of success in his favor.
He will return to Texas backed by

"Distance lends enchantment to the view"

My information in regard to the organi-
zation of the Univ is meager indeed -

[Header]

[1882 Feb 26]

I think the appointment of Judge
Thomas an excellent one. He is
a man of large brain & marked
individuality - He has a mind of
his own. I think the "Unlocking"
of your Interest Dividend will
prove a Trojan horse in the end.
I don't care how specious the plea.
The State can & will provide for the
perpetuity of the Col. School at
Hempstead - Its existence is better
or as well assured without a part
of your A & M Fund, as the A & M C. is
with it all. - No party in Texas
will allow the School at Hempstead
to go down - It is an important
factor in Texas politics.
I must forbear at present.
You see from the papers that Gov.
Hubbard has lost both his little
boys - I had the most touching
letter from him a few days ago
I have ever read. I have a grandson
at Huntsville. Don't wait so long to write

[Signature]

Your friend. Dana
